ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class included a live virtual discussion section as well.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class gave a look at some of the most important moments and themes of African Independence, through great discussions in section with Yasmina and through Dr. Machava's wonderful lectures.
I gained a framework for understanding the decolonization process in Africa and how it affected the social, political, and economic development of modern African States.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A strength of the class is Dr. Machava's wide breadth and depth of knowledge of the decolonization and postcolonial eras in Africa, from politics, culture, policy, history and more. Because it is kind of a survey course, it is difficult to get into true depth; but that is more a factor of limited time than anything else. Dr. Machava was fantastic.

Professor Machava does an excellent job with the lectures and the assignments are very clearly oriented towards the overall goal of the class. I have two small criticisms: we read a good number of wall street journal articles which did not feel very helpful for the material of the class, I would have preferred more of the scholarly works. Second, I think I would have preferred either a longer final exam or longer final paper rather than a shorter version of both.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual course was as best as it could be, given the virtual circumstances, thanks to Yasmina and Dr. Machava!
Virtual Lectures were great. Virtual discussion sections are very difficult, but Yasmina did as good a job as could be expected.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in Africa or postcolonial concepts generally. It was wildly fascinating to learn!
I would certainly recommend this course, especially as African history is really underrepresented in both the Yale History Department and broader American education.
